admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is satisfactory, with
            sustainability likely. The credit played a critical role in
            assisting the government to implement the structural reforms
            covered by the Second Structural Adjustment Credit Project
            (report no. P7165), most notably in the financial, energy,
            and health sectors. It was, however, less effective in other
            areas. Overall, both World Bank and Borrower performances
            were rated satisfactory. Lessons learned concern: designing
            appropriate capacity indicators to reflect some future
            desirable level of performance; aptly gauging the pace of
            change when using a technical assistance credit to finance
            institutional reform; avoiding having the International
            Development Association finance a daily newspaper as an
            attempt make government policies more palatable to the
            public; keeping better records for lending operations to
            maintain institutional memory; and engaging the government
            early in order to gradually transfer direct project
            implementation to government units.
